segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on locally security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on locally security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on locally security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on locally security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users can start an interactive session on the device.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users can start an interactive session on the device.

segment.source: Users must have this user right to log on over a Remote Desktop Services session that is running on a Windows-based member device or domain controller.
segment.target: Users must have this user right to log on over a Remote Desktop Services session that is running on a Windows-based member device or domain controller.

segment.source: Note: Users who do not have this right are still able to start a remote interactive session on the device if they have the Allow logon through Remote Desktop Services right.
segment.target: Note: Users who do not have this right are still able to start a remote interactive session on the device if they have the Allow logon through Remote Desktop Services right.

segment.source: By default, the members of the following groups have this right on workstations and servers:
segment.target: By default, the members of the following groups have this right on workstations and servers:

segment.source: By default, the members of the following groups have this right on domain controllers:
segment.target: By default, the members of the following groups have this right on domain controllers:

segment.source: Restrict this user right to legitimate users who must log on to the console of the device.
segment.target: Restrict this user right to legitimate users who must log on to the console of the device.

segment.source: If you selectively remove default groups, you can limit the abilities of users who are assigned to specific administrative roles in your organization.
segment.target: If you selectively remove default groups, you can limit the abilities of users who are assigned to specific administrative roles in your organization.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: Restarting the device is not required to implement this change.
segment.target: Restarting the device is not required to implement this change.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Modifying this setting might affect compatibility with clients, services, and applications.
segment.target: Modifying this setting might affect compatibility with clients, services, and applications.

segment.source: Use caution when removing service accounts that are used by components and by programs on member devices and on domain controllers in the domain from the default domain controller's policy.
segment.target: Use caution when removing service accounts that are used by components and by programs on member devices and on domain controllers in the domain from the default domain controller's policy.

segment.source: Also use caution when removing users or security groups that log on to the console of member devices in the domain, or removing service accounts that are defined in the local Security Accounts Manager (SAM) database of member devices or of workgroup devices.
segment.target: Also use caution when removing users or security groups that log on to the console of member devices in the domain, or removing service accounts that are defined in the local Security Accounts Manager (SAM) database of member devices or of workgroup devices.

segment.source: If you want to grant a user account the ability to log on locally to a domain controller, you must make that user a member of a group that already has the Allowed logon locally system right or grant the right to that user account.
segment.target: If you want to grant a user account the ability to log on locally to a domain controller, you must make that user a member of a group that already has the Allowed logon locally system right or grant the right to that user account.

segment.source: The domain controllers in the domain share the Default Domain Controllers Group Policy Object (GPO).
segment.target: The domain controllers in the domain share the Default Domain Controllers Group Policy Object (GPO).

segment.source: When you grant an account the Allow logon locally right, you are allowing that account to log on locally to all domain controllers in the domain.
segment.target: When you grant an account the Allow logon locally right, you are allowing that account to log on locally to all domain controllers in the domain.

segment.source: If the Users group is listed in the Allow log on locally setting for a GPO, all domain users can log on locally.
segment.target: If the Users group is listed in the Allow log on locally setting for a GPO, all domain users can log on locally.

segment.source: The Users built-in group contains Domain Users as a member.
segment.target: The Users built-in group contains Domain Users as a member.

segment.source: Group Policy settings are applied through GPOs in the following order, which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Group Policy settings are applied through GPOs in the following order, which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Any account with the Allow log on locally user right can log on to the console of the device.
segment.target: Any account with the Allow log on locally user right can log on to the console of the device.

segment.source: If you do not restrict this user right to legitimate users who must log on to the console of the computer, unauthorized users could download and run malicious software to elevate their privileges.
segment.target: If you do not restrict this user right to legitimate users who must log on to the console of the computer, unauthorized users could download and run malicious software to elevate their privileges.

segment.source: For domain controllers, assign the Allow log on locally user right only to the Administrators group.
segment.target: For domain controllers, assign the Allow log on locally user right only to the Administrators group.

segment.source: For other server roles, you may choose to add Backup Operators in addition to Administrators.
segment.target: For other server roles, you may choose to add Backup Operators in addition to Administrators.

segment.source: For end-user computers, you should also assign this right to the Users group.
segment.target: For end-user computers, you should also assign this right to the Users group.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can assign groups such as Account Operators, Server Operators, and Guests to the Deny log on locally user right.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can assign groups such as Account Operators, Server Operators, and Guests to the Deny log on locally user right.

segment.source: If you remove these default groups, you could limit the abilities of users who are assigned to specific administrative roles in your environment.
segment.target: If you remove these default groups, you could limit the abilities of users who are assigned to specific administrative roles in your environment.

segment.source: If you have installed optional components such as ASP.NET or IIS, you may need to assign the Allow log on locally user right to additional accounts that are required by those components.
segment.target: If you have installed optional components such as ASP.NET or IIS, you may need to assign the Allow log on locally user right to additional accounts that are required by those components.

segment.source: IIS requires that this user right be assigned to the IUSRComputerName account.
segment.target: IIS requires that this user right be assigned to the IUSRComputerName account.

segment.source: You should confirm that delegated activities are not adversely affected by any changes that you make to the Allow log on locally user rights assignments.
segment.target: You should confirm that delegated activities are not adversely affected by any changes that you make to the Allow log on locally user rights assignments.
